Class MinMaxDivision

  • java.lang.Object
    • MinMaxDivision

  • public class MinMaxDivision
extends java.lang.Object
    You are given integers K, M and a non-empty zero-indexed array A consisting of N integers. Every element of the array is not greater than M. You should divide this array into K blocks of consecutive elements. The size of the block is any integer between 0 and N. Every element of the array should belong to some block. The sum of the block from X to Y equals A[X] + A[X + 1] + ... + A[Y]. The sum of empty block equals 0. The large sum is the maximal sum of any block.
    Version:
    Oct 27, 2015
    Author:
    Tyler Hagerty

      • solution

        public static int solution(int K,
                           int M,
                           int[] A)
        given integers K, M and a non-empty zero-indexed array A consisting of N integers, returns the minimal large sum.
        Parameters:
        K - The number of blocks to divide the array into according to the rules stated above
        M - The maximum value an element in A can be (will be ignored)
        A - The array of integers
        Returns:
        The minimum large sum of A when divided into k blocks

      • isValid

        public static boolean isValid(int K,
                              int proposedLrgSum,
                              int[] A)
        Checks if a value from the binary searching of the minimum large sum is actually obtainable.
        Parameters:
        K - The number of blocks A must be broken up into.
        proposedLrgSum - The number binary search has given to be tested if it's a valid, obtainable large sum
        A - The array of integers being broken into blocks
        Returns:
        True if the number is obtainable as a large sum under given conditions, false otherwise.
